newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian brokers lower expectations for Chidambaram.
newsitem.headline: Indian brokers lower expectations for Chidambaram.

text.p: India's fragile stock markets still hope Finance Minister P. Chidambaram will steer them out of troubled waters, but brokers are lowering their expectations for his economic policies, analysts said on Wednesday.
Dealers and analysts say the internal politics of the 13-party coalition government will likely prevent Chidabaram from making major changes to his budget proposals.
"People have high hopes of market-friendly measures," said broker Maulik Sharedalal of Vipin Chinubhai & Maulik. "Those hopes could be belied."

The market was waiting for the finance minister to ease a controversial minimum tax on high-growth firms and announce incentives to lure investors back by scrapping double taxation on company dividends.

Chidambaram was expected to make a statement on the 1996/97 (April-March) budget this week, but on Wednesday parliament was adjourned until Friday because of a row over political developments in Gujarat state.

Chidambaram was expected to spell out any amendments to tax legislation when he speaks for a second time just before parliament votes on the finance bill, which was supposed to be passed by the end of the September 13 session.
But now the session could be extended due to this week's delays.

Analysts, however, say any changes are still unlikely to cure the ills of the local share market, which has been hit by a lack of retail investors and declining foreign interest while being brushed aside by cash-starved domestic funds.

"I really don't think he'll give (the market) a boost. He might make some token changes -- and that will be bad," said Kamal Kabra, a top broker and former president of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).

The 30-share BSE index was up 14.08 points at 3,498.76 in mid-afternoon trading on Wednesday. The market has plunged 570.5 points, or 14 percent, since June 18, nearly three weeks after Deve Gowda was sworn in.
"An upsurge will be short-lived," Sharedalal said. "Ground realities will catch up. Basically it's a problem of huge supply."
The potential excess supply came from budget proposals like the issue of non-voting shares and divestment of state holdings.

The government plans to raise funds through divesting its holdings in some firms, while Indian companies plan to raise more than $1.5 billion through issue of global depositary receipts listed overseas.
Sharedalal said there was a need for government policies that would encourage a stronger inflow of funds into the system to absorb the supply.
Such policies could include public provident funds to invest in stocks, he said. The government could also recognise bank investments in divested stocks for statutory liquidity reserve requirements.
